pros: Pay is competitive. There are opportunities to build a diverse portfolio and grow your career. Regular employee satisfaction surveys allow you to share your feedback (ask to see the latest from Leading Edge if you're interviewing here).
cons:
The organization lacks direction and clarity, reporting that there are direction changes without details or consistent messaging. Leadership gets in their own way and doesn't trust employees at any level to make decisions based on their experience and expertise. Leadership feedback often feels manipulative and/or condescending. Many positions/roles lack clarity and don't have defined expectations.

I also want to note that a few years ago when a member of leadership noticed negative reviews on this site, they asked some employees to write good reviews and dismissed the previous reviewers concerns.

pros: Good job for growth and development
Teams work collaboratively across departments, and there is real value added to the Jewish community based on the work at HGF.
cons: Upper management could (and are actively trying to) improve standard processes on raises, transparency, evaluations.

pros: Great coworkers outside of the executive tier. Actual mission is profoundly satisfying.
cons: Terrible workplace culture BY DESIGN. The executive leadership openly has little respect for employees and constantly feels employees are trying to "pull a fast one" or "get away with something." This likely is carry over from leaderships' past time in the for profit sector. But suffice to say, I have never worked at a nonprofit that believed so strongly its employees did not value its mission. Afterall, if employees wanted to bill by the hour for boku bucks they would not be working at a nonprofit foundation dedicated to Jewish culture and engagement. People are fired  or quit frequently, and others are constantly being monitored for signs of apparent laziness. The benefits are, not surprisingly, awful (zero paid maternity leave or personal time, with minimal sick and vacation accrual rates). You really have to believe in the mission of the Foundation to work here, which is why the management's paranoia is so sad.

review_title: Great mission, fun people to work with, excellent benefits
pros:
Challenging work that is hardly ever boring
Modern technology, tools
Openness to new ideas, new approaches to solving problems
Many hardworking, fun people to work with
Learn about Jewish culture
Healthcare benefits are the best of any place I've worked
Good vacation plus several Jewish holidays off
Nice campus to walk around on breaks during Spring and Summer
cons: One of the challenges at HGF is communication and coordination of large projects between technology and business teams.  However this is not surprising given the amount of growth the foundation has had and the scope of the projects underway. It is a great opportunity for people who are really good at being a liaison between technology and business teams.

review_title: Comfortable, friendly work environment; benefits are ok
pros:
* friendly work environment 
* pay is pretty good for the region 
* lots of learning opportunities
* perks like free thanksgiving meal for your family, veggies from farmer’s markets, gifts from Harold himself 
* lots of collaboration within departments
cons:
* benefits are not great. Vacation time is limited. 
* not a lot of collaboration between departments
* some of the management are quite ageist and do not want to hire older people, or think that older workers are not as capable 
* staff and organization is not very Jewishly knowledgeable for a Jewish organization
